In the tropics I would have expected a more lush botanical gardens. Whilst the oldest botanical gardens in Hawaii it appeared that more money needed to be invested in the gardens for them to fulfill their potential

title: Kaimana Beach, Honolulu
review_list:
Great place to parf affordable and to watch the friday 19;45 Hilton fireworks each week. Great trees, close to Zoo, public bathrooms. Need change to park; ask hotel and the will give you a whole pack of quarters (in return for a 10 bill off course)

wonderful place to relax in the sun, read a book or newspaper or just watch the world go bye. Great place to bring picnic lunches, hang with friends. Parking is always a premium so come early or later in the afternoon.

Very nice beach to relax and dip in the water without fear of huge waves. Great for families with young children. Can get crowded especially on the weekends.

Love coming here because you can actually swim without huge waves wiping you out. It's a local gathering place so family oriented and easy going.

South of the aquarium . Not a lot is shade and can be windy. Quiet, not crowed yet only a 15 minute walk from Kuhio beach in Waikiki

Beautiful beach right across the Kapiolani park.It's wonderful for a lovely walk by the clear blue waters.

Bring your snorkel gear and underwater camera! You and NOT going to want to miss the marine life that will be swimming along side of you. Beautiful fish and small sea creatures. We were lucky enough to share the water with sea turtles!!! Priceless!!

I love this beach. Its mainly a local beach and dog beach. Its close to the Natatorium. Usually easy parking, and lifeguards and shower. At the hotel overlooking the beach there is a small convenience store for snacks etc. No shade! Bring an umbrella or walk to the grassy area by the showers and you will find benches and trees...

I have been coming to this beach for over 35 years. My keikis( children) went swimming here at this safe beach. The reef protects it from big waves, just right for the little ones. The best beach , very calm and safe for the children . You can take a spot near the HILTON VILLAGE and watch the fireworks , just ask the schedule.

title: Queen Emma Summer Palace, Honolulu
review_list:
Beautiful setting. Small but interesting museum with easy parking. Can walk through the back to a large park.

We visited this palace with our three and five year old daughters. We would recommend avoiding bringing young children here, as the guided tours are more for adults interested in the history of Hawai'i and its people, rather than for children with short attention spans. The house and its contents are lovingly preserved and children have a tendency to want...


More  



A small cottage packed with personal items from the royal family. In particular there are several Royal garments made from bird feathers. One robe required over one million. Furnishings are very European Victorian in style. Signage, one small sign right at the entrance, is hard to see before you pass the site. Worthy of a visit to get a closer...


More  



Had a great docent., Wonderful history of the family and Hawaiin history. Sad what we did to their culture. Beautiful furnishings. My husband and I both love old houses and this was a treat.

This is a lovely old home that gives you a little bit more history of Queen Emma. You can walk into each room and see beautiful carved furniture and old settees. Beautifully maintained, not a large exhibit, but well done. Barbara the woman taking admission was very informative.

Queen Emma Summer Palace is a gem just outside of Honolulu city. Beautifully maintained by the Daughters of Hawaii, this palace captures the spirit of Hawaiian royalty during the period of the monarchy. Be sure to notice the standards made of feathers and the adorable cribs for royal babies.

We took a bus to see this. We had a great tour and explanation of everything. We were there a few years ago and not on this trip, but if you like history, it is a great place to visit

Queen Emma did much for Hawaii. She had this palace (actually a DIY home from Massachusetts) built high above Honolulu in a beautiful location. Many artifacts from as far away as England as Emma and Victoria were friends. Emma started Queen's Hospital and is important history of the islands. Travis gave us an stupendous tour.

I lived in Kailua for 5 years, and now we have a vacation rental condo in Waikiki, so I have driven past the Queen Emma Summer Palace on the Pali Hwy probably hundreds, if not thousands, of times. However, I had never visited this historic place. Finally, one rainy day, we decided to stop by and check it out.

We were there for the Smithsonian Museum weekend. We thought the house and grounds were well maintained, with some interesting information and artifacts concerning Queen Emma. I liked this better than the palace.

My wife and I went on this tour on Christmas day - and it was amazing! All the crew made us feel welcome and really brought the day to life. We saw dolphins, turtles and so many other amazing sights under the sea. They even provided a vegetarian and gluten free lunch for us at very short notice.

This site is very beautiful and in a very exclusive part of Oahu. Beautiful beach mixed with expensive multimillion dollar homes truly looks like paradise. The spitting cave is awesome, beautiful, but also dangerous. Just be cautious and use your judgment to ensure your safety as well as others. Follow appropriate precautions as enjoy the cave.

This place is gorgeous! Dangerous but freakin gorgeous! We went here with friends and they took some engagement pictures for us. You would never find it unless you were actually looking for it but defiantly worth it. You feel like your on the edge of the world! Enjoy and be careful!

title: Food Pantry, Honolulu
review_list:
Food pantry is situated close to the Ohana west hotel,so is convenient for those late night munchies and/or a glass of beer and bubbly.

A good option to purchasing food and fruit to have instead of having take away fast food. Central to Waikikki beach.

Still expensive...$7.99 for miracle whip!! But, when compared with the resorts a much better choice.

This is a great place to stock up on everything. The Aussie dollar is not good and so eating out for all meals is expensive. This place you can get everything you can think of.

With a Food Bean coffee shop and HI Steak takeout restaurant. Place is overpriced compared to other already expensive local supermarkets. It is a place to eat less expensively than the outrageously priced restaurants in Waikiki.

A grocery store in Waikiki which has a range of groceries for those who are self catering. Prices are reasonable given the location and fresh fruit is of good quality.

Started the day with coffee and bagel at the entrance to the food pantry - big servings.
The food pantry is convenient, price competitive and has most things you need. Saved a lot of $$$$ eating stuff brought from here.

title: Downtown Honolulu, Honolulu

Downtown Honolulu is dumpy and dirty. Lot's of homeless people sleeping in doorways . Not much shopping except Walmart and Ross. Restaurants consisted of a bunch of fast food restaurants. There's really not much of a reason to go downtown.

Enjoyed walking around downtown, both in the afternoon and evening. Lots of shops, restaurants and places to take a break when walking around. Good view of the harbour as well. Never felt unsafe at night, but there were a lot of homeless people/druggies walking around at night.

You can expect the shops and eateries to be open quite late - so it was easy to get about and enjoy the nightlife.

Great place to walk, shop, people watch. Traffic a hassle so best without a car. Loads of restaurants, gift shops. Waikki Trolley runs constantly and the city's public transportation system is super.

there is always a lot of people downtown, and when the sun goes down the street walkers come out, ladies of the street and drug heads. A lovely quiet escape with plenty of great shops and food outlets. There is a Fun Factory for kids. Great cinema complex. Ala Moana is great for shopping but this mall has a much quieter and relaxing atmosphere.

Air conditioned mall with some lovely little shops and a brilliant supermarket called a Whole Foods specialising in organic and local food. Cinemas included and lots of food places and seating.

A small comfortable van takes you comfortably to the north shore and back. Our guide was attentive to the van temperature and passenger limitations. More  



Our guide Greg, was very informative and a great guy.
The trip stops at the Byodo-Inn temple, Lizard Head Rock, North Shore, Turtle Town and Dole Plantations.
It was a most enjoyable tour and our family of four (including two teenagers) had a great time.
It's a pity that Haleiwa doesn't allow buses to stop.

Mandy our tourguide, was the most informative guide we have had in our trip to Hawaii. Her passion with nature is contagious. The hike was good, although would probably not pick a weekend next time. It was crowded but the view was worth it. Would book more tours from this company!

Have just spent a amazing day touring the island. Our guide Paul made sure that we got the most out of the day, ensuring that we saw as much as possible and fully explaing what we were looking at. He is a credit to the company. If you only book one tour I highly recommend this one.

it was a blast going to the flea market if u have the chance go its great lots of cool things to buy

title: Hawaii State Art Museum, Honolulu
address: 250 S Hotel St, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96813
review_list:
Well worth a visit, a relatively small but varied collection of works or art. Almost as interesting as the pieces themselves are the names of the donors, who reflect a history of Hawaii.

Stumbled upon a flyer for an exhibit at the Hawaii State Art Museum, so I decided to check it out. I was pleasantly surprised. The exhibits were excellently curated. The grounds were interesting. The docents were very knowledgeable, and security officers respectful. Thoroughly enjoyed my visit. And it was free. Although I didn't try it, the cafe looked good too.

This museum is well worth the very short visit it takes to see all the exhibits. They don't have a lot, but what they do have is unique. You get the vision of current artists and sculptors. The rooms are tastefully laid out to isolate each item and show it at its best. There is a cafe on premises that...


More  



I love art museums. Every time I travel I visit several. I love taking the time to appreciate every piece. I came to the Hawaii State Art Museum with high hopes of seeing traditional Hawaiian art. I was disappointed to find mostly modern pieces that depicted aspects of Hawaii. I left the museum only a quarter of the way into...


More  



I accidentally stumbled across the Hawaii State Art Museum while looking for the Honolulu Museum of Art. This beautiful little museum is funded by The APP (Art in Public Places) Program. The program was created in 1967 with...

I did not think that l would have enjoyed this Museum, but how wrong was l, its a must see on your bucket list.

so much history in one building, we learn so much about hawaii and the islands and the area. great for kids and parents alike. take a tour and you learn so much, very fun place.

The art and sculptures are interesting. A nice museum and it is free. Some Saturdays, there are activities for kids. Do check them out.

title: Kuliouou Ridge Hike, Honolulu
review_list:
My 11 1/2 year-old son and our two friends (age 17 & 18) started the trail at 0900. Not really early so parking was pretty far away (~0.5 miles).
The first two-thirds of the trail have an easy grade. There are a lot of switchbacks to summit but the scenery makes it worth it. There are a few breaks in...


More  



most of the way up its a switch back trail but once you get to the top the views are breath taking. perfect for couples as well as families with kids

My 21 yr old son and I (55) enjoyed this hike along winding trials through interesting forests interspersed with spectacular views. Especially enjoyed the norfolk pine forest and views of diamond head to wnw and Rabbit Island to the ssw. For best views, do not end your hike at the picnic area, or at the metal bench a little further...


More  



This is a beautiful, and even romantic, hike. You get great views on all sides, and the hike is not too difficult, either. I recommend it for sure!

I've been on many Oahu hikes and Kuliouou continues to be my favorite. More  



Overall this was a great hike. The view at the top was amazing. The hike is challenging from the perspective it was muddy in spots plus you hike over slick tree roots. That aside it was an enjoyable hike to the top. It is steep near the top however the Sierra Club install stairs that help ease the climb to...

Despite getting clouded out ... this is a good, tough trail. The first half of the trail is relatively mild with a pretty gentle uphill and lots of switchbacks. This place makes no sense to me. It's the same stuff you can get in all the other stores but more expensive. Why!? It's massive and like a luxury mall maze. I think it's for people with too much money who don't want to walk through the mall.

Not really a good duty free option as it is way expensive. You are far better to select from a smaller selection of goods and retailers at the factory outlets, much cheaper !!!!

If you are no Japanese do t bother to visit they like Japanese cause their spending money it is expensive and not worth when you can get the same things in mainland Usa and at a cheaper price just go window shopping.

LIKE the one in hong kong and other mayor cities this is great famous brands nice clothes, nice cosmetics
they also are very nice, and offer a free beauty concierge

If you are a high end international shopper than the 3rd floor might just be for you (if you take your passport), but for me there really wasn't anything that I was interested in. title: Honolulu Harbor, Honolulu
review_list:
I like boats, ships, the ocean - but there is nothing here. You may be lucky and have a few unique boats in, be careful of the barges people make into looking something other than it is (pirate boat)

Watched the cruise ships come and go. Visited the Aloha Tower, where you can do some shopping and grab a bite to eat. Clean, lots of places to take a seat to relax. Not much more to do other than that or venturing into downtown.

I went to Honolulu Harbor to go on the whale-watching cruise. The harbor was pretty & clean. The cruise was fantastic! We saw some whales, although they were pretty far away. The ship was very nice. They have a nice restaurant.

I've been to Oahu twice and it is always exiting, while being moving to my soul. This Island enriches my soul in every way. In memory of sacrifice and bravery, I will never tire of the sights and lessons of Pearl Harbor.

One of many harbors around Honolulu, this harbor is mostly industrial with Aloha Tower being its centerpiece. There are a few restaurants there plus lots of Hawai'i Pacific University students, as well as the two cruise lines that ply the waters three times a day, giving tours and insight.

Some changes there, but lots of boats and ships to see. Aloha Tower shops now dorms and classrooms but tower still there to go up and enjoy the view.

I have been to the Waterfront there isn't much to see or do unless u go about down to where are the boat tours are. I know this is comparing apples to oranges but I've been to Seattle's Waterfront now that was something spectacular ours is boring.

This is a nice place to walk or sit for a while. My husband and I even ran through here a couple of days during our stay in Honolulu. Get a feel for a modern day fishing village!

Magnificent place to drive or walk around. Great place to stop and eat or to pick up one of the many tours, cruises or dinner cruises. Top location.

Honolulu Harbor is a nice area to walk around and relax while taking a look at all the boats and ships in the area. It's nice to watch all the incoming and outgoing traffic. We found several places to eat and drink around the area although we didn't try any of them. A good way to kill a little time.

title: Ward Centre, Honolulu

review_list:
Our concierge recommended Ward Village when we were enquiring about Waikele and we are glad we followed his advice. Great value and a huge range of stores and products.
Took The Bus from Waikiki for $2.50 but needed a taxi back with all the shopping.

Most Australians head to waikele outlets, ward centre is about a 15 minute walk from ala Moana away from Waikiki, worth it for Nordstrom rack, Ross, sports authority and famous footwear outlet. I end up with shoes every time. Try ward centre for excellent shopping.

We love the Ward Village different events during the year. At Christmas they have an outdoor ice rink. At other times Sunday Brunches and then the Hawaiian dancing called the hula. Shopping at TJ Maxx, Nordstrom Rack, Pier 1 Imports, Bed, Bath & Beyond is loads of fun as well as the surrounding area's restaurants. You can spend a day...

Cannot stop shopping here. TJ Maxx and Nordstrom rack have better brand discounts than the bigger Ala Moana and Outlets. Great cosmetics, sunglasses, active wear - get to Ward! It's very close to Ala Moana and not very advertised. Give yourself some time to sort through those clearance racks!

Just down the road from Ala Moana the Ward Centre shops are great for variety and to find a bargain. TJMaxx, Nordstrom Rack, Pier Imports, Sports Authority and Ross just to name a few. You can also combine shopping with some entertainment and catch a movie while you're there. The large cinema is great and don't forget that Tuesdays are...


More  



One of my favorite boutique in Honolulu, I discovered the brand in a boutique in San Diego Coronado island. Over 135 shopping and 40 dining options. A lot of the shops are unique to the centre. The shops are spread out over several streets, which means lots of walking.

I visited the Ward center because of the fabulous stores; Nordstrom Rack, TJ Max and Pier 1 imports. Just a few kilometers up from Ala Moana Shopping Mall is a Honolulu shopping secret. I always find shopping bargains at these stores with less fuss than the big mall.
A must visit when shopping in Honolulu.

I was so glad I visited the Ward Centre and Ward Village on a recent visit to Hawaii. I had been to Ala Moana Shopping Centre twice and did not purchase anything, though I was interested in homewares, jewellery, Hawaiian-inspired products, clothing, shoes, accessories and gifts.

This is the place you would go back home, away from the tourists per se. All the normal mall stores, and some good local restaurants that you might like to try. I always grab some HCC cookies when visiting Hawaii. First time visiting this store and was really impressed with the level of service I received. Great cookies combined with great service...what more could a tourist want??

We were treated to some free samples upon entering the store. We brought one small box of cookies home with us. I liked the coconut cookies and my wife liked the pineapple ones the best. They will ship for you or you can order on the internet.

These cookies are absolutely delicious!! The stores are all over town. When you walk in (or even walk by) the fragrance of fresh baked cooked sets your taste buds off. Thought of getting some of these cookies as gift for people. Decided that they don't transport well, very expensive for just a few cookies and that people would not appreciate the cost for a cookie that was just okay.

We were walking back from the beach when we came across this shop and were invited in for some samples. These were the most amazing cookies I have ever had! I ended up purchasing a beautiful tin of cookies to bring home to a neighbor.

Was so excited to find this store at Waikiki beach. My hubby treated me to a box, because he knew how much I loved them the last time I visited.
Not cheap, but the more you buy, the cheaper they get. And they really are amazing!

Mine are any of the coffee based chocolate dipped cookies! yum! they make great gifts for the family back home. Take some Aloha with you!

a must-see place to visit..they have the best cookies in honolulu..plus you can try their free sample cookies if you can't decide immediately...good for take home presents back to family and friends in mainland USA.

A cute little shop that you can get all different kinds of Hawaiian styled cookies. I loved walking by, because they are always offering samples.

title: Hawaii Convention Center, Honolulu
review_list:
This building shows the tropical-themed architecture and history of Hawaii. Very roomy and "kick-back' casual conventions. See the history of the islands in the design and decoration.

Attended a convention here today, and was spruced how fresh and new it felt.
Nice facilities, good climate control in meeting halls.
Lots of nearby restaurants and hotels.

I attended a conference recently and found that location is good and there are many hotels nearby. The center is well organized, easy to move around and no problem in locating different rooms.
Good things
Clean center and well organized
Nice location and easy to access
Bad things
Only a few restaurants near by and food is expensive

I'm an exhibitor and participated in a medical convention here. The location is convenient and the conference center is clean. The staff is easily accessible and friendly as well.

Major brand hotel convention and we received top notch service each and every day. Great mixed use space with outdoor/indoor areas. Very impressive.

The design its self is worth seeing. Absolutly beautiful. Hope you enjoy seeing this treasure of the island.

The center is within walking distance of Waikiki hotels, close to Ala Moana Shopping Mall, and easy to get to by bus. It is adjacent to a public park/walkway along Ala Moana canal. title: Hawaii State Capitol, Honolulu
address: 415 South Beretania Street, Honolulu, Oahu, HI
review_list:
It's worth a stop here to see the building architecture and view the Queen Lili'uokalani Statue. Last Queen in Hawaii. She also wrote their national anthem On the day we visited there were many happy people who just became citizens, smiling and waiving there certificates.

Directly next to Iolani Palace the capitol building is an interesting design with an open courtyard and assembly halls on each side. The fountains seem to need repair but over all an impressive building.

Worth a visit. Interesting building to look at and learn more about why it was built the way it was. Wish I had taken a guided tour, but time-wise could not.

Makes a nice photo op but offers little more of real interest to the visitor. Its a real deperature from the mainland capitiols in style

And I've visited 25.
First, the homeless people. They're everywhere. If pointing that out makes me cruel and heartless, then you give them food and cigarettes and money and leave me out of it.
Second, the capitol itself has no discernible place for visitors. Every other state capitol I've visited makes the house chambers available for viewing when the legislature...

This is a must see Kodak moment. The incredible building design is best appreciated when you enter the internal courtyard. Look up and be amazed...

There's so much to do in Hawaii and this likely doesn't top your list. HOWEVER - it was very informative and I would highly suggest going. The building doesn't look that interesting on first glance, yet it is once you learn the story and meaning of its features. The capitol is truly different than the other 49 capitols. It's also...

We had a tour and it was very interesting hearing about the building and what everything represented

Hawaii's state Capitol Building is the newest/youngest of the 50 state Capitol buildings because Hawaii is the newest and youngest state in the Union. The legislative chambers and offices are built around a large replica of a volcano to remind visitors that all of the Hawaiian Islands were formed by volcanic activity having built up from the ocean floor over...

This is an amazing, open air building. The state senate is on one side, and the house of representatives on the other. The middle is wide open, as is the roof. As we went in a little off season time, we found Chinatown to be worth a visit, because many stores were not too busy. As such we ended up in a place where we found shopping deals as good as the ones in Hong Kong and we left with a big smile and plenty of shopping bags. We also had...

there is nothing special about Honolulu's Chinatown - unlock San Francisco's.
some good restaurants, that's about all.

Been to much larger, better Chinatowns with more authentic food. Just walked around and did not end up staying long as it is quite small.

This is barely big enough to be called a Chinatown. And at night, there are only a few places open. The food wasn't that good either. The hutongs of China are cleaner and safer. You can definitely scratch this from your bucket list without missing much.

We mostly visited just to look around but ended up finding some awesome food! Excellent Manapua, and we found some delicious Bulgogi! Enjoyed watching some ladies string fresh flower leis. Definitely an interesting experience.

Not a place where we felt at ease. Felt like an unpleasant neighborhood...kinda strange crowd there...lot of trans people, but no one who looked friendly or open...bit unwelcoming scary place

Honolulu Chinatown is small and about 15min walk from the Lolani Palace. There are quite a few restaurants around the Chinatown Cultural Plaza and also along Maunakea St. It is a lot smaller than NY Chinatown. Dim Sum in Legends Seafood restaurant was good.

Definitely not a place to visit at night! It was quiet and not a safe place to visit, in particular with a family! We weren't told not to go to Chinatown by the taxi driver who dropped us off at the Honolulu Christmas Lights at City Hall, so we walked there! I wished we didn't venture off. Thankfully, we quickly...

All the really cool bars and loads of fine restaurants, art galleries and music venues are here all in a 4-5 square block walking area. Parking is always tricky on the street but try the Chinatown Parking garages.

Love the Lion Dancing and celebrations during Chinese New Year. Other then in February this place is not really anything for tourists or locals to do around this area.

title: Saint Andrew's Cathedral, Honolulu
address: Queen Emma Square, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96813-2304
review_list:
The church is of course a place to worship, but the congregation is willing to share the history and offer a descriptive brochure to point out the significant and historic features of this magnificent place. There are special services during the year which honor the ali'i so check the calendar on the church website in case you are visiting when...


More  



We were there in November and the Chirstmas décor was very spectacular.Large quiet place. Restful stop.

Kawaiahaʻo Church, the other more promoted church in Honolulu, may call itself Hawaii's Westminster Abbey, but St. Andrew's Cathedral is the real Westminster Abbey of Hawaii (if there's such a thing).
The seat of the Episcopal Church (the American sister denomination of the Church of England in the Anglican Communion, the third-largest Christian denomination -- behind Roman Catholics and Orthodox...


More  



Very beautiful Gothic-style church in Honolulu and worth a quick visit. However, I wouldn't go out of my way to see it. Instead, pair it with another Honolulu attraction, such as the Iolani Palace or the National Cemetery.

We went there on a week day. A pianist was playing some hymns at the church. The church has some of the most beautiful stained glass. You may get away from the hustle and bustle in downtown and have a quiet moment with God, or just to clear your head.

St Andrew's Cathedral is a lovely building, historically important, religiously significant to the State of Hawaii. But it ALSO has a superb organ and choral programme, run by John Renke, longtime organist of the Cathedral. Apart from his involvement in the usual liturgy of the church, the organist has for many years run a weekly recital series on Wednesdays at...

After Queen Emma's Summer Palace we just had to check our St. Andrew's Cathedral. Wow! It is so beautiful. Built in 1867, it is a glorious place to experience the peace that passes all understanding. It must be seen and felt to be truly experienced but pictures do tell some of the story. And the fountain, although only decades old,...

I've driven past this church many times. It has the shape of most churches here in Hawaii. Then one special day Rev Desmond Tutu came to speak & I went to see him. This church is beautiful inside! There are carved statues & beautiful stained glass windows. If course they didn't have enough pew space to seat the crowd that...

We were fortunate to be in Honolulu on a Wednesday because that is when the Cathedral has its noontime concerts (also on Fridays). I had discovered this fact online before traveling to Honolulu. A beautiful setting, beautiful music, a beautiful day.

In addition to the wonderful art experience, the positive and gracious people in the church are clearly representative of God's love. The Holy Spirit definitely dwells here and is felt the minute you enter the Cathedral.

title: Honolulu Beerworks, Honolulu
review_list:
Have been there twice already on our current trip to Oahu. Great beer selection ... Best pretzels I have ever had! And even corn hole on the patio. Staff super friendly and accommodating ... Will be back!

I honestly really enjoyed this place. The front of the lounge is all open air and looks really cool. It's a nice chill environment and very friendly servers. I personally liked the beer flights.

Being that I turned 50 this year; what do I know from "Hipster"? Nothing, that's what! What I can say, is this: I thought the overall concept or layout of the place, was very well thought out. I've usually stopped here as part of a Paradise Pedals outing. Good beer, interesting ambiance. Worth a stop on a night walking around Kaka'ako. Be sure to Uber or taxi home after tasting the variety of local brews.

We enjoyed this place so much we came back the next day for beer and lunch. Had the antipasto salad. Extremely fresh and delicious.

Visited twice. Tried all the beers via the tasting flight which was good value. Good lunchtime food - salads and the Reuben sandwich particularly good. Easy to get to on the bus.

Tasty beers with a good spread of variety. Friendly staff. Relaxed atmosphere. Another good recommendation from the Brew Dogs.

title: Aloha Trikke, Honolulu

review_list:
It was a great experience with a nice tour guide and views, thank you for making this happen to me! Will definitely recommend to my friends who will be going to Hawaii!

Great rates and service. We booked a circle island tour and luau from Waikiki but got confused on the dates and so missed one of our luau. We went to the office and were rebooked on a new luau at no extra cost. Certainly could have turned out differently with a less customer first attitude.

A great experience a must do when in waikiki this tour has more value than advertised my daughter & I had a great tour with AJ....AKA Mr Aloha he gave us history and some great sights as we zipped around on those kick butt trikkes....

Aloha Trikke is a no brainer. Why would you visit Waikiki and NOT do this! Best ever!!!! Awesome people and the greatest way to see Oahu. Especially, if you are with someone who can't walk because of arthritis, old age- they can still see the tourist spots with the best view! Totally recommend it!! Don't miss out 👍👍👍

title: Honolulu Hale (City Hall), Honolulu
address: 530 South King St, Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96813
review_list:
Going to the event, after leaving discovered our electronics devices where not in the car. IT was a Friday evening. After going on-line to google and trying many ways to get a phone no. to an open office (security or anyone especially since the event is open late in the evening) of this event is impossible. You have to wait...


More  



An annual tradition of families in Hawaii is to tour the decorated trees and wreaths at City Hall aka Honolulu Hale. From the majestic tree on the front lawn to handcrafted wreaths on the inside there's something for all ages to enjoy.

This is a lovely building in the middle of downtown Honolulu. Worth walking by, even if you don't have time to go in. The architecture is a little different from the rest of the architecture in the rest of the city.

Each year the Christmas tree lighting is a gala event with a spectacular parade, carnival-like food booths, and entertainment. The ceremony itself is fashioned in a manner that each mayor, since Mayor Frank Fasi first established this event, personalizes. Just one night, once a year. It is delightful.

A nice building that uses a large lobby to often house exhibits and community issues, Honolulu's City Hall is a beautiful building. It is well lit at night and is the center of holiday lights in December. There is nothing more to see as you pass (really) on your way to the State Capitol, the Mission Homes or Iolani Palace.

Honolulu Hale is the political seat of the City and County of Honolulu. "Hale" meaning "home" also implies a meeting place. The mayor and City Council have offices here and public meeting rooms are open. Don't forget to go to the basement. The photos of all of Honolulu's mayors line the wall. Art exhibits are usually featured in the main...


More  



We were looking for authentic historic Honolulu buildings, but did not come across any on our first day there. The second day we happened to find Honolulu Hale, City Hall, which was built in 1927, originally as a Spanish mission. We were surprised to learn from the Civil War display in the lobby, that 200 sons of mostly abolitionist missionaries...


More  



We took a trolley during the City Lights Tour. Honolulu Hale was just beautiful! A grand building with alot of charm. There must have been 30 Christmas trees decorated by diff. city depts. Santa was there to greet the little ones.
Outside, there is a huge Norfolk pine decorated with many colorful lights. An easy walk will take you past...


More  



I am not joking when I say that there were more kids and parents lined up along the parade route than at Disney's nightly closing parade ceremony! I wish towns on the mainland were as enthusiastic about Christmas as much as this city is.
The parade was disappointing. We thought we were towards the end of the parade route and...


More  



Great tropical-themed Christmas displays in and around City Hall. Go at night when It is all so colorfully lighted; the kids will be mesmerized and you will be delighted to see the happy expressions on their faces. Best of all it is free.
Displays inside the City Hall rotunda are produced by the various city departments so the competition for...


More

title: Koko Crater Botanical Garden, Honolulu
review_list:
This garden is unique among those on Oahu. Parking is free but the lot is not very large. We were a little surprised by the lack of care on the paths. A significant portion of the first half is up hill. Many of the paths have loose stone. This is not a visit for baby strollers or those not sure...


More  



Nothing special about the garden having been to a few more impressive and bigger ones in the past. It features a decent group of plants from a few key areas. Strolled around it before heading to the koko crater rim trail.

Just like the title says, it is sort of interesting, but not very well maintained. The self guided tour is interesting but a lot of the plants are not labeled so it is tough to enjoy the entire hike.

My husband, 1 year old daughter and I visited this botanical garden and were impressed with it. As mentioned it is free of charge and there is a reasonable amount of parking available. It is not well manicured like other botanical gardens we have busted in the US but it is charming just the same. It is relatively quiet and...


More  



This is not a regular botanical garden with hundreds of plants from around the world, asphalt walking paths and crowds of tourists. Koko Crater Botanical Garden is actually a preserved piece of local Hawaiian land with local trees and bushes that would be considered as extremely exotic in any other place on Earth. There are several inclusions of plants from...


More  



Super disappointing. Granted, we did visit in Fall, so maybe that's why there weren't a lot of flowers or pretty plants/bushes/trees. Did the two mile circle so at least I got some exercise out of the deal. And I did get to see up to the top where I'd hiked a few weeks prior.
Wouldn't return even though it's free.

This attraction is free of charge, has plenty of parking, & a large variety of well-established plants, many of which were new to me. What particularly impressed me was the size of so many of them---planted in the 1950s with much room to grow, it's a treat to see them now as mature specimens. The "sausage tree" was particularly interesting...


More  



Not real impressed with this botanical gardens. Now I can see why it's free to get in. I would avoid a trip here. Go do something more fun in the area.

We found this gem totally by mistake. If you are not up to walking up the Koko Crater's main trail, this is a wonderful alternative. Enjoy the inside of the Crater and wonderfully maintained gardens and walking trails. It is hot and dry so take some water.

The crater was formed about 50,000 years ago and is a botanical garden for dry-land plants. It is “free” is taken care of by non-profit Honolulu Parks.
At the beginning of the trail is a box for a free guide listing the various types of plants and trees along the trail. The crater trail is a two mile loop.
It...

title: Sans Souci Beach Park, Honolulu
review_list:
If you want to escape the hordes at Waikiki Beach, consider coming here.
Just down the road a short 5-10 minutes, right near the New Otani Hotel. Parking can be a challenge...but where isn't it, in Honolulu :) Many fish in the clear water.
Clean sand, a bit more relaxing with terrific views of beautiful Waikiki.

This is a beautiful, peaceful beach at the end of Waikiki. It's far enough away that you don't get the crowds, but you get the same beautiful views!

At one end of Waikiki, this beach is usually uncrowded. The water is generally very calm. It is a short swim to a small reef. The reef is not spectacular but it is a good place for easy snorkeling. On most days, the water by the beach is great for toddlers. There are not many beaches as suited for them.

Great place; mostly tourist-free! So close to the hell of Waikiki but far enough away to keep most of the tourists away. I hate Waikiki due to the throngs of people. I was so surprised to discover this beach a few weeks ago while walking along the promenade. Very clear water and only a handful of folks there. The beach...


More  



This beach is at the shore of the new Otani where we stayed. It is a shared beach with the locals but only gets busy on the weekends. This is much better than Waikiki as it is not as busy and the waves come in at an angle leaving the beach at the resort very calm. The beach is right...


More  



God I love this place. Its so quaint and has the most beautiful beach on waikiki. Nice mix of locals and tourists and easy to get to but hard to find parking

I'm torn about writing this review. I almost want to keep this beach a secret! After an 8 day stay at the New Otani which is situated right on this beach, we absolutely loved the quiet local vibe at this beach vs the more crowded popular beaches of Waikiki. During the weekdays it’s fairly empty and on the weekends it...


More  



Beautiful strip of beach, rock pools and snorkelling only 15minute walk from waikiki beach.
Not many cafés or shops directly attached (about 10minure walk away) to it so take water/snacks
Great view of waikiki beach for photos

After driving through the Waikiki area, packed with the usual suspects having way too much fun. We ran into a park to get away from the crazy Beach action. Sans Souci Beach Park is at the end, so to speak, of Waikiki. It too had lots of people. But what seemed a much more mellow, laid back crowd. There's lots...


More  



We had a welcome ceremony for our conference at this Beach. It was really lovely and much quieter than further down towards the main strip at Waikiki.
There is lots of parking and it's not far to walk if you have to walk either. Close to the Zoo and Aquarium as well.
We really liked it hear and revisited later...

title: Lulumahu Waterfall, Honolulu
review_list:
This is a quick fun hike that takes you to the beautiful lulumahu water fall. It took me 30 minutes to get to the fall. We were casually hiking but never stopped until we reached the fall. Easy place to park and enter the trail

Best place to go and get way from the city. Great hike as well. Very unsure at first as there is signs for private property but still get to go fast that

Its not too hard of a hike and it is also not a long hike (max 1 hour one way)
However as you trek through the bamboo forest... Your feet will get soaked in water and definitely in some mud..be prepared!
The falls itself was nice to walk under!!
IL
When we went it was not busy at all..maybe 2-3...


More  



We did the Lulumahu waterfall hike with DONE tours. It was fabulous!! Our family of 4 had our own private tour guide who led us through the rain forest up to the falls. It was especially muddy and wet when we toured however our guide, Koko, was very patient and friendly to accommodate all of us on the hike. Koko...


More  



Lush scenery, surrounded in expansive tropical greenery. Pali lookout-spectacular views, hold on to your hat, very windy, but refreshing.

We enjoyed our trip here , learning more about Hawaii ....and the people who lived here in the past and now

Sky provided excellent safety instructions for this moderate yet slippery trek to a beautiful tropical rainforest waterfall of 120'. He identified many points of interest that free trekkers just went straight past. From micro to macro ease. His deep geological, botanical and historical knowledge combined with an easy going nature made this 21/4 mile low land velley trek a highlight...


More  



This hike is a great microcosm of Hawaii and the payoff to see the falls at the end was incredible. Plan on getting muddy - it's often wet and the first part of the trail is pretty well soaked after a rain. But oh so worth it. I went on a day that had off and on rain and the...


More  



It was so beautiful, it takes your breath away. The hike to see the falls is well worth it. the flowers and vegetation are amazing to see. It just added to the experience. Did I mention the smells another added bonus it smells wonderful.

If you are in the area go ahead and visit. But I would not make a special trip to go visit. It's okay but nothing spectular.

title: Ali'iolani Hale, Honolulu
review_list:
Visiting the royal palace provided some insight into the opulent lifestyle of the last Hawaiian dynasty. Unfortunately I suspect that the docent gave a somewhat slanted view of the royal family painting them more as victims of white imperialism while playing down their obvious excesses at the probable expense of the islanders.

5-O headquarters only on TV!
Ali'iōlani Hale was started in 1872 and completed two years later. Designed by Thomas Rowe, the building was originally going to be a palace and serve as the King's residence. But, this was changed and the building housed the Kingdom treasury, Supreme Court, and other government offices. Today, it continues to be the Hawai'i State...


More  



We were able to visit on Christmas Day. No traffic, parking up front, perfect! Although the facility was closed, we were able to walk around the building and check the landscape out. The old growth trees are amazing! So glad we made the stop!

Of course everyone recognizes this from Hawaii Five-o television show. The building itself is interesting with some unusual architecture.

Perhaps one of the most recognizable features of Oahu due to both the original series and the current as it is used in the opening credits. The building is architecturally beautiful. Across the street from Iolani Palace.

My boyfriend & I watch Hawaii 5-0 so we thought we should stop by here. It was very quick maybe a 10 minute stop. We parked on the side of the road using meter parking. It was cool to see just because we watch the show, other than that nothing too too special. We didn't actually go in the building...


More  



The history of Hawaiian law is explained here. The Supreme Court is actually in this building and it is still in operation. How they incorporate a museum and a court in the same building. Very informative.

We visited Ali'iolani Hale as part of our city tour. Interesting building with a chance for several photo ops. A must for 5-0 fans.

We didn't have much time to spend here but it is well worth taking a few minutes to see a key part of the history of Hawaii!

I was a little disappointed as we only had 15 min on the tour from Pearl Harbor. Would have liked to spend more time there. The statue of the King is what Hawaii 5O shows on there show.

title: Baileys Antiques & Aloha Shirts, Honolulu
review_list:
More aloha shirts than I could imagine, great selection of sizes also , for us larger type folks. Prices were reasonable also

This place is such a kick in the pants! We spent an hour looking through piles of Aloha shirts in great vintage styles and, best of all, great prices! You can spent a few bucks or hundreds of dollars on shirts here. We left with about five fantastic looking name-brand shirts. If you love Hawaiian shirts you will love this...

So you want an authentic Hawaiian shirt? This is the place to go....there are thousands to choose from here, from very affordable to vintage shirts from the 70's costing thousands....I found exactly what I was looking for, and landed up buying two shirts for myself! There are also antiques lining the shelves. What a great little find!

Bailey's is a great place to look for aloha shirts, with a HUGE range of styles from vintage to modern (although heavy on the vintage as advertised). There are both new and used shirts. The prices range from around $4 to more than $100, although most that I saw were in the $10-$40 range, with the next largest group being...

I saw this shop on trip advisor and after reading the reviews I just had to check it out for myself. Wow! Wow! Wow! Soo many shirts and cool vintage stuff. The proprietors really know a lot about Aloha shirts and it was lovely listening to them explain all about them to the customers. So much better than the touristy...


More  



I did not own a Hawaiian shirt, and did not want to buy one at home that was made overseas. This place is awesome - there must be thousands of shirts in there, both new and used. I ended up buying a used, authentic "Made in Hawaii" shirt for a very reasonable price. We got there close to closing time,...


More  



This shop is a bit of a legend and there is a lot to choose from if you are male . But at a price. There is also a limited amount of female vintage at the back. Staff are so helpful and chatty. Easy to lose a few hours here ....,if you love Hawaii shirts this is your Mecca !

We spent ages trawling through the new and used shirts in here, as well as the vintage décor and memorabilia. Tonnes of shirts, sorted by era, style, etc - more for guys than girls but I found that some smaller mens shirts fitted okay. Theres also jackets - leather, mechanic, military. I was overwhelmed for choice in the shirts department,...


More  



Wish I came here first before buying my Hawaiian shirts elsewhere. Plenty of selection for all budgets. Very friendly staff.

If you want an Hawaiian Shirt (and even if you don't) this is an incredible place to visit. The range of shirts is amazing (over 17000 I'm told) from totally over the top to ones you would wear to work. Should be on your must visit list.

title: Mission Houses Museum, Honolulu
address: 553 S. King St., Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96813
review_list:
We walked here from the Iolani Palace, Capitol building and past the adjacent church. We were on a parking meter, which limited our available time to visit for any length of time anywhere. We looked from the sidewalk, read the placards and our internet information, took pictures and hurried back to the car.

This is an interesting short guided tour of the places lived and worked in by early missionaries.. Does not need to be pre booked, tours run regularly and we just joined next available one.
Only a few minutes walk from Iolani Palace so recomend any history lovers who do that also do mission house. Small home made food style cafe...


More  



An apparent staff shortage the day we were here meant we were left without the opportunity to linger in any of the rooms long enough to read the info postings or even go into some of the rooms. The tour guide Mike was obviously knowledgeable, but literally locked the doors of each building as we exited. So it was a...


More  



Again, we like the history and it is one of the nicest places we saw. We even printed a paper. Would go again

Take the tour it is educational and you can try weaving , candle making, printing and pill making activities on grounds. There is a restaurant on site if you want to eat before tour and a gift shop.

Among the first formal buildings in Honolulu (and across the street from City Hall today), the Hawaiian Mission Houses is a National Historic Site and worthy of your time. It tells the story (through three guided tour houses) of the first Congregationalist missionaries who helped the locals construct a written Hawaiian language, and of course, changed life here forever with...


More  



The Mission Houses provides a great insight into the early missionaries in Hawai’i. The guided tour inside the buildings is a must.

We did an 11am guided tour (you can walk around outside but we paid for the tour - its worth it, and supports these places). Wonderful to visit the oldest wooden building in Hawaii, built by the missionaries. The tour was fun and informative, especially the printing press and information about the development of the Hawaiian alphabet and first HUGE...


More  



The Mission House was a housing kit brought to Honolulu by New England missionaries. A basement came as part of the housing kit. Basements aren't very convenient in Hawaii. The basement was really hot and stuffy.

This guided tour was most interesting. The guide was very knowledgeable and gave an very informed presentation of how the early missionaries settled on Oahu. The houses and gardens are very well maintained. Historic pieces within the house are also most interesting. The stories of the families who inhabited the home were also well told.

title: University of Hawaii at Manoa Campus, Honolulu
review_list:
Unless you are attending college all this place is good for is bird watching, and thats a good thing...Several species of bird on campus that are not seen elsewhere on the island..

Went on a field trip with a school and enjoyed listening to the indigenous Hawaiian tutors talk about how the University caters for indigenous Hawaiians. They specially welcomed us into a special house and took us for a tour of their waterways with it's history and took us for a campus tour of the sports venues, arena, campus store, looked...

I travel solo to Honolulu in order to enjoy the weather and visit local friends, but there are times when I need to self entertain. I like to walk so adventure far from the hub of Honolulu. Three times I have walked (uphill to get there but not terribly far) to the campus of Hawaii's Manoa Uni. Don't bother. Aside...

Get over there and take one in. Quality product on the floor. Game day staff works hard and is pleasant. A nice change of pace from typical tourist scene.

We were in search of University of Hawaii souvenirs and also wanted to see the campus. A ways from Waikiki but we got a cab there and took a local bus back. Great way to interact with the locals.

We recently toured the campus and dorms of UH. My daughter wants to major in Marine Biology. The campus is large and we were shown quite a bit on our walking tour. The old buildings have great character and most have been updated wit AC. Our guides were very friendly and knowledgeable. We also toured the freshman dorms which I...


More  



The University of Hawaii at Manoa is a beautiful campus, filled with heritage & character. The grounds are filled with trees & landscape native to the island.The people working there are friendly and more than happy to direct you to where you want to be.

I travelled to O'ahu to attend Summer School at UH Manoa. As a mature student this was a very interesting and rewarding experience!
There are a great variety of courses available and the instructors are outstanding. The centre for Hawaiian Studies (Kamakakuokalani) was a favourite place.
Student housing was very nice, with clean and well maintained buildings. The cafeteria food...

A big and nice place to study, located in Manoa Valey. Pretty convenience with shuttle bus to go around university. Sports, theater, market, bookstore, food, everything is here! you will also find a nice professor who can guide you with your research. This university is most likely focusing on research!

The nursing staff at U of H Manoa were so friendly and helpful. We were there on business and took a tour of their state of the art SIM lab. Wow, blew us away. If you are going into nursing you should go to this college! I wish I did!

title: Foodland Ala Moana, Honolulu
address: 1450 Ala Moana Blvd., Honolulu, Oahu, HI 96814
review_list:
Would have shopped if if had been their and opened but it's gone and the closest one is a good 20 minutes away, so guess what Don Quiote got our money and will continue to get our business

My fave grocery store at Ala Moana is gone gone gone. Options are nearby Don Quijote and Food Pantry on Kuhio. I miss Foodland's deli. Apparently a new one will open in the mall addition. In the meantime, don't bank on FL at AM for your tourist grub.

This grocery store is located in central Honolulu, one street of the main road. You can compare prices to Don Quijote and the Ala Moana grocery store and come out equal. It has a deli and fresh seafood daily. Also, importantly to me, you can buy newspapers from many Canadian and US sources. Their poke is delicious.

Since it seems like poke is (was) a star attraction at this full service grocery store, be sure to visit the other Foodland locations such as Market City and Beretania to buy poke!

Had to go here for the Ahi poke! Wow! Was it great. To have such a deli back home! The entire store was great. We picked up a half loaf of French bread and a bottle of wine and made a picnic with our ahi poke, muscles and kimchi crab.

There are plenty of options for places to eat at this food court. The biggest in Oahu as far as I know. There are several local eats here as well as a few places for dessert!

Love this store and the employees in it. Sadly it is closing. The Ala Moana Mall is renovating and raising rents. The Foodland Company announced that they couldn't justify staying. So sad, the store convenient, with a great poke counter. Great while it lasted.

We ALWAYS go to this store for poke, desserts and their deli. if you're staying in Ala Moana, they have everything you need for your stay. Fast and friendly service!!

Great variety of deli style foods and snacks. We bought half a lb of shoyu marinated ahi poke and ate it raw... Extremely delicious! You can't get ahi this quality back home in oz from any style market! Buy all you products and at the checkout mention you wish to become a maikai member, just give them your contact number...


More  



The announced recently that this store will close down next month and leave the mall citing rising rent as the main reason.

title: Ala Wai Canal, Honolulu
address: 1959 Ala Wai Blvd, Honolulu, Oahu, HI
review_list:
Take a stroll along the canal in midday to get out of the hot sun. Shade trees along most of the pathway. Watch the rowers. You will come to the Convention centre with it's water fall features.

This is one of my go to spots for running. It's a nice 3 mile out and back, no elevation. Plenty of side walk room not having to worry about bumping into people. Choice of pavement running or there is a bike/pedestrian cut trail in the grass. Best part not having to cross streets or worry about traffic. For a...


More  



I had a good view of this from my hotel (Aqua Pacific Monarch), but enjoyed walking along its bank early in the morning or at dusk. There are a number of parks along its banks and a golf course. Great to watch locals practising canoeing skills.

This is a nice canal, but the history is really interesting, too! This canal is basically why Honolulu and Waikiki are what they are today!

We had a great evening exploring Waikiki and its surrounding areas.The Ala Wai canal was a sweet surprise.Beautiful and serene.

i got what i was looking for! peace and quiet areas and when its party time, lots of them. shopping is super great! from knickknacks to MK's, and ross, fruits to spinach. everything was done right! you'll find everything under the sun in Hawaii!

If you're staying in Waikiki, there are several great running routes. Ala Wai is one of them, with a wide sidewalk and lovely views. If you find Kalakaua Ave really crowded (even at 6:30 am!), then check out Ala Wai.

We passed the Ala Wai canal several times coming and going to Waikiki. Seemed to be used mostly by rowers practising for events.

Not sure it's a visit more like you drive by it. On the trolley the driver went into some stuff about it. It was pretty cool to see how much after it rained the canal rose. Not something I would go out of my way to visit, nor did I get off the trolley to check it out.

My annual visit's hotel is close by. Every morning I take a brisk walk along the canal to the roadway bordering the zoo and head back on the main road. Every late afternoon I walk in the other direction en route to Ala Moana Mall for a food run. I enjoy the peace and quiet the canal offers, barely minutes...

We have taken our Preschoolers here. The Police Officers have been great in trying to bring the talks down to their levels. The children love looking at the different artifacts that they have in the museum. The hard part for them is remembering not to touch everything!

Such an interesting museum! Had Officer Chang around to ask questions of & he was very helpful & friendly. Although smaller than what you would expect, there...

This tour was awesome. A lover of history, it was fascinating to see over 100 years of Hawaiian history regarding our law enforcement hero's. Honolulu Police Department is the ONLY Police Department founded by royalty. The King of Hawaii began HPD many years ago. Officer Chang was kind and quite knowledgeable. This is a great dive tiki bar where you can get great cocktails at decent prices, forget paying $14 on the beach when you can basically get three for the same price...

The wife and I were in Oahu and looking for some local bars and unique places. This is definitely one of those. review_list:
I found out about this only from others reviewing on TA as it wasn't mentioned in any "standard" guidebook ---so glad I did! One is never disappointed when visiting here as you're likely to see a karate lesson, an ikebana class in session, or just enjoy a stroll through their grounds. Whenever we are traveling, we like to learn a bit of the culture that made the vacation spot what it is. This center will give you great background on the Japanese culture and the influence it has had on Hawaii.

The first Japanese to arrive in Hawaii came in 1806 and the influence of the Japanese is everywhere throughout the Hawaiian Islands..
The Center is home to a fascinating historical exhibit that informs of the various struggles and successes of Japanese immigrants to Hawaii. It features the Seikōan Teahouse which is a cultural and artistic practice on display. It contains...

This is an excellent place to see and learn about the history and culture of the Japanese in Hawaii. Interactive displays, short movies in a small theater, video clips, audio backgrounds, a walk through museum with well planned exhibits and a nice gift shop with many Japanese items. I was really impressed. It is located just outside of Waikiki. We...


More  



Great resource into a perspective of early 1900s. Deep ties between hawaiian and japanese cultures shaped our hawaii of today.

The 'Ohana Festival is an annual event at the Japanese Cultural Center of Hawaii. It features activities for the entire family including games and rides for children, music and other entertainment for all ages. Most interesting are the educational displays which explain Japanese culture and history. Admission is free. Food and souvenirs are available for purchase.

There are several places around Oahu that describe the Japanese American experience here, but this one emphasizes the cultural transformation from being a Japanese person in America to being an American who has ancestors that came from Japan. The Spalding House location of the Honolulu Museum of Art is a beautiful house, built in the hills overlooking Honolulu. You can get into the Spalding House for free on the same day as you go to the Honolulu Museum of Art, so I would advise doing that. We had lunch and wandered the grounds. The food was Greek inspired and YUMMY!!!! You can eat indoors, outside in front of the museum gift shop under a canopy. Or you can have a picnic on the grounds. We will go back again to see the art indoors another time.

Wonderful grounds. Great spot to getaway from midday heat & crowds down below. My favorite spot in Honolulu on a nice day. Don't miss it.

title: Royal Mausoleum State Monument (Mauna Ala), Honolulu
review_list:
Worth a stop if you are interested in Hawaiian history. The grounds are well kept and there are numerous other places to visit in the same general area.

This was one of our stops on our tour of Iolani Palace, and Queen Emma's Summer Palace. Beautiful grounds and lots of history.

Reverent, peaceful last resting place of most of the Hawaiian monarch and their descendants. The ONLY piece of land that remains in Hawaiian kingdom/crown lands. It is sovergin Hawaiian Land. Visit the final resting places of the Kamehameha and Kalakaua lines.

Walking down here from the Queen Emma’s Summer House is well worth it. It only takes about 20 minutes to visit.

It is important to know that if you are visiting Mauna Ala that it is a very special place to Hawaiian people and culture. It is the place where Hawaiian royalty is buried. title: San Souci Beach, Honolulu

this small theatre in the middle of a graveyard ( that's right) is a gem. Its season usually consists of Six contemporary broadway and offbroadway plays with the best local talent in the Islands. Staging is imaginative and the quality is first rate.

On the opposite side of the island from the USS Arizona is the USS Utah Memorial where another of the three battleships that were sunk on December 7, 1941 and not repaired still rests. How refreshing it is to find a gallery in Honolulu that's not full of Wyland whales or some of the other tourist trinkets that Honolulu is known for.
